comments.body: you can show hashValues in the import
+1 to the comprehensive documentation with example.
Thanks!
I find this paragraph hard to understand. Maybe add an example?
Or add an "See also" entry linking to SemanticsSortOrder, which seems to explain this in more detail.
Added the See also.
Should this include the `nextNodeId` if set? I imagine it might be useful when you debug traversal order. And this is what gets printed out when you hit "S" during a hot run.
Good point.  Added.
I was under the impression that the accompanying engine PR completely removed geometric comparison from the platform side? What's left to move?
And without that, what is actually now breaking ties?

As we discussed, nothing is breaking ties.  The order of a tie is currently arbitrary, until I've implemented the geometric comparison again on the framework side.  It doesn't help to continue to compare geometry on the engine side, since they're all assigned `nextNodeId`s already.

Can we document somewhere around the setter/getter for nextNodeId (or for _updateNextNodeId) what setting this to -1 means? Especially, does it mean: Not followed by any node? Or the order of the next node has not been defined?
Done.  It means not followed by another node, and is the value that the last node in the list gets.
pass in topRight when direction is null, so we're more likely to catch regressions where someone starts depending on it

Well, I wouldn't say it's typical. There are two main ways to use it: either specify the entire string of keys in one go, replacing whatever the hierarchy built, or specify one at each level of the widget hierarchy.

I'd say something like "If only one key is needed, using the constructor's `key` argument is less verbose."
I guess I don't really understand how this works. Can you suggest some sample code I could include here to explain what "keys" does?
glad to see you are using ifEmpty here!
Maybe I missed it, but should there be an assert somewhere to ensure that you have explicitChildren set when you set this? Or are there use cases where it is actually ok to not do that?
I've add an assert to the semantics render object, since that seems like the right place (can't use the const constructor)
Does the sort key still have to be its own data type? Why do we not simplify this to be just a double now?

A `double` value is undocumentable, so it's unclear what it means to have your nodes sorted together with nodes authored by someone else. The numbers would look magical in the source code. But if the sort keys are provided by _one_ author then they can define and use a custom type.

Let's say I have four semanticsNodes A to B that are all siblings and that specify a custom sort key. The default traversal order sorts them as follows:

A: FooSortKey(3.0)
B: FooSortKey(1.0)
C: BarSortKey(1.0)
D: FooSortKey(2.0)

My understanding is that this algorithm would sort these nodes to [B, A, C, D], but I would have expected to see [B, D, A, C] (or possibly [C, B, D, A]). No?

That would be ambiguous as demonstrated by the [B, D, A, C] vs [C, B, D, A] conundrum. I think if your nodes rolled up to a common parent but with different types, chances are that different keys came from different branches of the UI hierarchy, and the most reasonable default is to sort within that hierarchy. If your intention is to sort across branches of the UI, you would provide keys of the matching types.
I don't know where the appropriate place is, but it feels like we should document this somewhere.
Is the unstableness of sort also a problem for non-null sort keys that are equal? Will sort put these in "random" order?
Correct. I do not expect this to be a problem though. If you are specifying explicit keys, it does not make sense to supply equal keys.

Actually, because we are sorting by `_TraversalSortNode` there's no way you can have this situation. `_TraversalSortNode` uses list position in paint order as the tie breaker, so there's no way you can get two equal `_TraversalSortNode`s.
Looks like everythingSorted could just be a `List<SemanticsNode>` from the beginning to avoid this conversion?
I'm not sure how this would work. Only `_TraversalSortNode` knows how to sort by sort key.
Slight confusion: Doesn't this method also get called for lists of length one that don't have overlap per definition?
Yeah, it's one of those "Are all elements of an empty set blue?" kind of situation. It's just a special case. But I made it clearer in the docs.
bonus points: would be great to link to the graphic from you slides here.
Done.
to avoid all this mapping, can search not operate on semanticsnodes and sortedIds be a `List<SemanticNode>`?

It uses the position in the list as a tie breaker to guarantee that the sorting is stable. So for now I think this is the most idiomatic method. I also measured the efficiency of the entire algorithm across many of the Flutter Gallery screens. It never exceeded 100Âµs on Moto G4. This is not surprising as the `SemanticsNode` tree is very sparse compared to the `RenderNode` tree.
Great doc comment!
ðŸŒ®
Can you document what iOS does when this is set?
Done
Should this doc also be updated to the version you are using above?
Do you mean the CustomSemanticsAction doc comment?
Just curious: why the hash list?
we have an assert in `ui.hashValues` that fails for iterables - not sure how it didn't catch this before, or if it is new.
This is a great doc comment. Many copy'n'paste it to this property's namesakes?
A diagram would probably help a lot here
Done, see section below. The embedded diagram can be previewed here: https://github.com/flutter/assets-for-api-docs/pull/52/files?short_path=a0d507c#diff-a0d507c94a0c10e017f62b301780d2d4
Diagram definitely helps.
this might deserve a breaking change announcement
Done: https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/flutter-announce/Y1TG0CNgsM8
The diagram can be previewed here: https://github.com/flutter/assets-for-api-docs/pull/52/files?short_path=a0d507c#diff-a0d507c94a0c10e017f62b301780d2d4
A comment in `proxy_box.dart` implies that `null` is a valid value for this field. Let's document what null means vs others.
We should specify exactly what we mean by "characters" here
Added clarification.
Maybe also define what inout focus means?
That's what the `(indicates that the node will receive keyboard events)` was supposed to be doing, I think. I reworded it.
Same as in the other PRs, we already know that other is assignable to CustomSemanticsAction.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +130,134 @@    if (other.runtimeType != runtimeType)
      return false;
    return other is CustomSemanticsAction
        && other.label == label
        && other.hint == hint

comments.body: Same here.
Do we want to mention that it throws if they aren't the same type, or is that not something we document specifically like that?
Well, it's assumed that we enforce the contract. It's OK to say it asserts, but not necessary if you say that something "must" be a certain way.
If they aren't the same `runtimeType`, should we return here for non-debug builds?

One of the main reasons to use asserts to enforce the contract is to avoid a lot of code for checking the contract in release mode that slows things down, and this, while it's just a conditional, just adds overhead to programs that abide by the contract.  Once the contract is violated, then all bets are off anyhow.

Also, what should we return? It seems like it's possible that it would do the "right" thing if they have different types, but at least one of them has a name.
